awd_titl_txt: Winning Approaches for Talented Transfers in STEM (WATTS)
awd_abstract_narration:
Webster University in St. Louis, Missouri specializes in 4-year Bachelor of Science degrees in Biological Sciences with an emphasis in Chemistry, Research and Technology, or Computational Biology, or a Bachelor of Arts in Biology with an emphasis in biodiversity. The "Winning Approaches for Talented Transfer Scholars" (WATTS) project will support 51 academically talented students from feeder Community Colleges (CC) to pursue degrees as full-time students.

The project will include a research study on the implementation and effectiveness of new strategies to recruit and support transfer students through successful STEM degree completion. The study and the project evaluation will examine the role of alumni and peers as mentors; the role of corporations as partners in education and the development of workforce-ready graduates. The effectiveness of practices for comprehensive institutional alignment and communication on behalf of the specific needs of STEM students, transfer students, and the larger undergraduate student population will be studied to promote the preparation of students for careers in science through rigorous course work and independent/collaborative research projects. The WATTS program will provide crucial transitional counseling, mentoring, and peer/buddy support before, during, and after transfer. Graduating biology majors will meet the growing demand by area employers for STEM expertise in the St. Louis region workforce, where biotechnology is among the area's most prominent industries.  Conclusions drawn from the results of the research study and the evaluation will be used to inform decisions on the institutionalization of effective components.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Webster University (WU) was awarded an S-STEM grant entitled Winning Approaches for Talented Transfers in STEM (WATTS): Award #156463; amount awarded $647,669; average amount of scholarship $9,857 per year; number of scholarships awarded: 27 students, 3 left the program; retention rate 86%; 

Description of the project activities: Year 1: First 3 WATTS scholars were enrolled in fall 2017, and additional three in spring 2018. In the first cohort, one scholar dropped out to pursue a degree in a non-STEM area. Project activities included orientation meetings in fall and spring with Directors of First-Year Experiences (FYE) and Career Planning and Placement. Students were enrolled in a one-credit course “Careers in Biological Sciences” which covered resume building, networking, interviewing, and involved alumni and potential employers. Students helped organize a career day tour to two different locations. In spring 2018, we hosted the first Discover the Sciences event for CC students and their advisors. It included a panel of our first cohort of WATTS scholars. Year 2: Seven scholars enrolled in the fall and one in the spring. We graduated our first two scholars in May, only in two years. Along with the orientations and career tour (expanded to three different locations, with student input), we started hosting invited speakers in various scientific fields. Scholars had the opportunity to interact with speakers by taking them to lunch, and greatly enjoyed this informal interaction with researchers and mentors. One of the WATTS graduates obtained employment as a result of the career tour. Year 3: Five WATTS scholars enrolled. We had our third career tour, with two locations chosen by the students, and invited a total of four outside speakers to discuss their research in biology or chemistry. Year 4: Three final scholars enrolled. Two additional students left in the spring 2020 (mainly due to COVID); however, they were replaced by other qualified students. COVID affected nearly every aspect of our usual interactions with the scholars. In particular, our orientation and other various WATTS meetings, Discover the Sciences, and speaker events became virtual. We were forced to cancel the career tour scheduled for April 2020 and were not able to plan one for spring 2021. Two WATTS scholars participated in summer REU programs, one of whom won an award for the best presentation at the University of Pittsburgh in summer 2020.

We were awarded a NCE in Fall 2022, that went into effect for Spring 2023. We enrolled 6 additional students who were set to graduate in 1-2 semesters, all of which had entered as transfer students. The final students from the NCE graduated in Dec 2023. 

Intellectual Merit/Lessons Learned:

  1. Attempts to use some social media (FB, Twitter) failed, however WATTS students did engage in GroupMe chats which increased communication and camaraderie among the students and faculty.
  2. The Discover the Sciences event started as an effort to recruit more students proved effective.
  3. Peer mentoring was difficult to get started and didn’t maintain momentum each year. However, during the transition to remote learning due to COVID, collaboration with the Office of FYE has led to more rigorous training of WATTS scholars as peer mentors for students in STEM, and the creation of the Student Coaches for Remote Learning (SCRL) program. 
  4. Services deemed as most impactful by WATTS scholars were: cohort meetings, guest speakers, industry tours, and faculty advisors/mentors. Most used services: faculty advisors/mentors, guest speakers, career planning.

Publications: WATTS scholars co-authored three publications with Co-PI Groeneman (see biosketch and References); Presentations: Schroeder, S., Groeneman, R.H., Preuss, M.L. “Winning Approaches for Talented Transfers in STEM (WATTS),” NSF S-STEM Symposium, Washington, DC, September 12, 2019.

Schroeder, S. and Gilbert, C. “Webster University Increasing Access for Science Scholars”, Presentation for Missouri Department of Education Council on Articulation and Transfer Meeting, February 2, 2018. 

 

Broader Impacts: The average time to graduation for all students was be 2.38 years. This was a significant impact in the community where students must work to support themselves and their families while in college. The project also improved collaboration with two community colleges.

 


Last Modified: 12/06/2023
Modified by: Stephanie C Schroeder
por.por_txt_cntn:
Webster University (WU) was awarded an S-STEM grant entitled Winning Approaches for Talented Transfers in STEM (WATTS): Award #156463; amount awarded $647,669; average amount of scholarship $9,857 per year; number of scholarships awarded: 27 students, 3 left the program; retention rate 86%;


Description of the project activities: Year 1: First 3 WATTS scholars were enrolled in fall 2017, and additional three in spring 2018. In the first cohort, one scholar dropped out to pursue a degree in a non-STEM area. Project activities included orientation meetings in fall and spring with Directors of First-Year Experiences (FYE) and Career Planning and Placement. Students were enrolled in a one-credit course Careers in Biological Sciences which covered resume building, networking, interviewing, and involved alumni and potential employers. Students helped organize a career day tour to two different locations. In spring 2018, we hosted the first Discover the Sciences event for CC students and their advisors. It included a panel of our first cohort of WATTS scholars. Year 2: Seven scholars enrolled in the fall and one in the spring. We graduated our first two scholars in May, only in two years. Along with the orientations and career tour (expanded to three different locations, with student input), we started hosting invited speakers in various scientific fields. Scholars had the opportunity to interact with speakers by taking them to lunch, and greatly enjoyed this informal interaction with researchers and mentors. One of the WATTS graduates obtained employment as a result of the career tour. Year 3: Five WATTS scholars enrolled. We had our third career tour, with two locations chosen by the students, and invited a total of four outside speakers to discuss their research in biology or chemistry. Year 4: Three final scholars enrolled. Two additional students left in the spring 2020 (mainly due to COVID); however, they were replaced by other qualified students. COVID affected nearly every aspect of our usual interactions with the scholars. In particular, our orientation and other various WATTS meetings, Discover the Sciences, and speaker events became virtual. We were forced to cancel the career tour scheduled for April 2020 and were not able to plan one for spring 2021. Two WATTS scholars participated in summer REU programs, one of whom won an award for the best presentation at the University of Pittsburgh in summer 2020.


We were awarded a NCE in Fall 2022, that went into effect for Spring 2023. We enrolled 6 additional students who were set to graduate in 1-2 semesters, all of which had entered as transfer students. The final students from the NCE graduated in Dec 2023.


Intellectual Merit/Lessons Learned:

Attempts to use some social media (FB, Twitter) failed, however WATTS students did engage in GroupMe chats which increased communication and camaraderie among the students and faculty.
The Discover the Sciences event started as an effort to recruit more students proved effective.
Peer mentoring was difficult to get started and didnt maintain momentum each year. However, during the transition to remote learning due to COVID, collaboration with the Office of FYE has led to more rigorous training of WATTS scholars as peer mentors for students in STEM, and the creation of the Student Coaches for Remote Learning (SCRL) program.
Services deemed as most impactful by WATTS scholars were: cohort meetings, guest speakers, industry tours, and faculty advisors/mentors. Most used services: faculty advisors/mentors, guest speakers, career planning.



Publications: WATTS scholars co-authored three publications with Co-PI Groeneman (see biosketch and References); Presentations: Schroeder, S., Groeneman, R.H., Preuss, M.L.Winning Approaches for Talented Transfers in STEM (WATTS),NSF S-STEM Symposium, Washington, DC, September 12, 2019.


Schroeder, S. and Gilbert, C. Webster University Increasing Access for Science Scholars, Presentation for Missouri Department of Education Council on Articulation and Transfer Meeting, February 2, 2018.





Broader Impacts: The average time to graduation for all students was be 2.38 years. This was a significant impact in the community where students must work to support themselves and their families while in college. The project also improved collaboration with two community colleges.
